Before going nto the details of fowl, the groups in the classification of vertebrates are ecapitulated here in brief.
isces or fishes: All fishes live in salt- or fresh-water.
They have several paired and npaired fins that help in swimming.
They breathe through gills, and the body is overed by scales.
Most fishes lay eggs.
Examples include hilsa, ruhi (salmon), atla, mrigel, puthi, koi, boal, shul, gojar, shing, magur, ayer, tangra, meni, oopchanda (pomfret), ritha, coral, shark, and so on.
Aves: Vertebrates that have feathers and can fly are called birds and are included in the group of aves.
Birds have beak but no tooth, and have lungs for respiration.
They lay eggs from which the young ones are hatched.
For example, ducks, hens, pigeons, sparrows, kites, parrots, kingfishers, crows, cuckoos, and so on.
Mammalia: The most superior of the vertebrates are mammals.
These give birth to young ones or babies that feed on mothers milk, and the body is covered with hair.
Lung is the organ of respiration.
Bats and titmouses can fly but their body is covered with hair.
Again, whales and dolphins live in water but they give birth to babies and feed them on breast milk.
They have no gills, but have lungs for respiration.
For example, cows, buffalos, goats, dogs, elephants, horses, tigers, monkeys, chimpanzees, human and so on.
They have a hairless, featherless, scaleless body with soft bare skin.
They have four legs and fingers, but no nails.
The eggs and larvae of the amphibians do not survive without water.
Reptilia: Some of the animals in this group live in water and some on land.
Some can live both in water and land.
They move on the ventral aspect of the body.
Lung is present, skin is rough and may be scaly, and they usually have four legs with nails.
For example, tortoises, lizards, snakes, crocodiles, and so on.
Fowl : Fowl belongs to the class aves of the phylum vertebrate.
Domestic fowl is reared in most homesteads in Bangladesh.
It is an important source of protein food.
Currently in Bangladesh, rearing of domestic fowl is a profitable business, and a mode of self-employment too.
What follows is a description of the external and ninternal body features of a domestic fowl.
Head: The part of the body extending from the upper end of the neck to the front end of the beak is the head.
The structures in the head include eyes, nose, ears, pinna of the ear, head comb, neck comb, and beak.
It pecks at food and strikes the enemy with the beak, sees with the eyes, and hears with the ears.
Functions: Wings help the fowl to fly.
Domestic fowl cannot fly much, but the wild fowl can fly a considerable distance.
It protects the chicks with the wings, also strike and drive away enemies.
Tail: The tapered part at the back of the trunk is the tail.
The feathers of the tail naturally help the fowl to maintain balance during movement and flight.
It helps the fowl to stop suddenly when rapidly moving.
Leg: Like other birds the domestic fowl also have lower limbs that consists of thigh, knees, ankle.
Instead of feathers, the ankle and toes are covered by small scales.
Each leg has four toes with sharp pointed nails.
The under surface of the toes is padded with soft tissue.
Functions: The domestic fowl moves about with the help of legs.
It scratches the soil with the legs to extract food, and drives away enemies.
Feathers: Like other birds, feather is a special feature of the fowls.
Three types of feathers cover the whole body.
The feathers on the wings and tail are bigger.
The most prominent feathers are called contour feathers, or pennae.
They make up the wings and tail of a bird.
Functions: Feathers serve as protection against rain, extreme temperature, and injury.
It also maintains the body temperature.
Its main function is to aid in flight.
Functions: Muscles help the fowl to move about quickly.
It also helps in respiration.
Skeletal system: The characteristic feature of the fowl is its skeleton.
The bones are hollow and light but strong.
The fore limbs have been modified to serve as wings to help in flight.
The size and shape of the bones are adapted to maintain the characteristic body shape.
The sternum, synsacrum, humerus, and femur are some of the noteworthy bones.
Internal Body Features: The internal structure of the fowl comprises of the muscular system, skeletal system, digestive system, excretory system, and reproductive system.
Muscular system: The muscular system of fowl is quite different from those of other vertebrates.
The main muscles used in flight are pectoralis major and pectoralis minor.
Digestive system: Domestic fowl do not have teeth, they swallow their food, and so their digestive tract is a bit different.
The crop is situated in the middle of the digestive tract after the oesophagus, which hold the food.
Following the crop is the muscular gizzard, which helps to grind the food.
From here the food is passed on to the stomach.
There are two major parts in the digestive tract of the fowl.
One is predominantly glandular and the other is muscular.
The muscular part is the gizzard or gila.
When taking food or grains, fowls sometimes take in small pebbles.
During the muscular contraction in the gizzard these pebbles help in the grinding of food.
Grinding is the function of teeth in other vertebrates, but in fowls pebbles carry out the function of teeth in the gizzard.
Absorption of the nutrients occur in the intestine and the waste products of digestion are eliminated through the anus.
Circulatory system: The circulatory system comprises of heart, arteries, veins, capillaries, plasma, red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets.
The heart has four chambers'right and left auricle, and right and left ventricle.
The heart is continuously contracting and relaxing.
During relaxation, the impure deoxygenated blood passes from the right auricle to the right ventricle, and is passed onwards to the lungs.
The oxygenated blood from the lung passes to the left auricle, from there to the left ventricle, and onwards to the aorta or great artery.
Arteries and arterioles distribute the blood throughout the body.
Lungs: Fowl have a pair of lungs contained within and attached to the chest cavity.
Fowl respire through the lungs.
The lungs are connected to a set of air sacs that changes shape to pump the air, while the lungs stay the same shape.
This unique system is an extremely effective way of extracting oxygen from the air, and it enables fowls to fly.
Excretory system: Parallel to the vertebral column, and on either side of it is a pair of dark brown kidney.
Each kidney is segmented into three parts.
The ureter from each kidney empties into the cloaca.
Reproductive system: In male fowl, beside each kidney is a testis.
Sperms are produced in the testes.
In the female fowl, there is only one ovary.
The ovarian duct opens into the cloaca.
The open end of the ovary is like a funnel.
First the egg yolk is produced in the ovary.
Over the yolk membrane there is a minute egg.
On maturity the egg yolk slowly slides down.
The egg is enclosed in a whitish liquid, the albumin.
This albumin is the white portion of an egg.
As it further slides down, the calcium carbonate producing glands secrete a shell around the albumin.
This shell is initially soft, it later hardens when in contact with air.
From the ovarian duct the egg then passes to the cloaca from where it passes out through the anus.
Normally this egg when kept warm or incubated under the hen for 21 days, hatched and chicks come out.
The eggs can be hatched artificially by incubating them in an incubator for 21 days at a temperature around 390 centigrade.
As a nutritive food, eggs come after milk.
The fowl meat is easily digestible, and can be eaten by people of all ages.
Currently, fowl farming is an important mode of self- employment.
Presently, many countries in the world are earning huge amounts of foreign currency by exporting eggs and fowl meat.
The feathers are used to make sports goods, and other luxurious articles.
The excreta of the fowl is an excellent fertiliser, and is also used as fish feed.
Features of different breeds of improved fowls: Among breeds of economic importance are four groups of fowl.
All these fowls can be reared in the climatic conditions of Bangladesh.
The names, features and descriptions of different varieties of fowls are given below.
Some of the breeds are Rhode Island Reds (RIR), New Hampshire and Plymouth Rock.
Some of the breeds are Leghorn, Minorca and Ancona.
Leghorn: There are many varieties within the Leghorn breed.
Among them, the white Leghorn produces the most eggs.
A full-grown fowl weighs about 1.5 to 2.5 kilograms.
They lay more than 300 eggs a year.
Leghorns are world famous for laying eggs.
Rhode Island Reds: This breed produces good quality and quantity of eggs and meat.
Hence rearing of this variety is profitable.
The body is brownish red, and may weigt about 23 kilograms.
They lay about 150 eggs a year.
They survive well in Bangladesh climate.
Australorp: This breed is well known for its meat and eggs.
The body is wide, and is greenish black in colour.
A full-grown fowl may weight 23.5 kilograms, and lay about100120 eggs a year.
They are more resistant to fowl diseases.
Aseel: This breed is seen in Chittagong and Brahmanbaria of Bangladesh.
This variety is famous for cockfight.
A full-grown fowl may weight 1.53 kilograms, and lay about 4060 eggs a year.
Fowl Rearing Process: In Bangladesh, mainly three processes are used for rearing fowl or hens.
These are'open space rearing, confined space rearing, and caged rearing.
As it roams around it eats grains, leftover food, vegetable peels, seeds, fish scales, animal viscera, insects, pebbles, and so on.
Sometimes, the owners feed them too.
During rain and storm, and at night, they take shelter in small coops where hens, cocks and chickens all huddle together.
As a result they do not get sufficient light and air, and so are often afflicted by different diseases.
The hens tend to lay eggs at unspecified places that are eaten by cats and dogs.
In this type of rearing the fowl have to be provided with food, and the coop has to be cleaned regularly at 23 days interval.
Besides, the fowl are protected from predators and other enemies.
It is more profitable to rear fowl by confined space rearing method.
Caged rearing: In this method the fowl are reared in cages made of wire.
More fowl can be easily reared in less space.
The floor of the cage is made of closely netted wire.
A tray is placed below the netted cage floor.
The faeces collect on the tray after passing through the net.
The tray has to be cleaned every 23 days.
The cage floor is also inclined forwards so that the eggs laid roll forwards.
The size of the cage may vary, it may also be in 24 layers or multi-storied.
For sufficient light and air, it is convenient to place these cages in the verandah or open space.
If improved breeds are reared then they have to be given a balanced diet, and any disease condition has to be promptly attended to.
